resources.string: A Native Android Application that demonstrates Secure Mobile Development Practises.
Welcome. Clicking this button on each view inside the App will give you more information about the different security measures implemented.

The Authentication and Access Control is provided by the OpenID Connect standard. The Open Source Identity and Access Management Server, Keycloak, is being used as the Identity Provider. \n\nThis App uses the Authorization Code flow and saves the tokens to Shared Preferences.

The notes are encrypted automatically when saved locally. It supports 2 storage options, using file system or sqlite. 

 When saved in the file system, each note is saved in its own file, and encrypted with its own secret key. The secret keys are persisted in the Android Keystore. 
To encrypt the files, AES is used. The key size is 128 bit, with GCM mode to ensure the integrity of the data. 

 When saved in sqlite database, SqlCipher library is used to encrypt the whole database. 

 For Android versions below 23, the secret keys can not be generated using the keystore. Instead, a KeyPair is generated in the keystore, and the secret key is generated separately. Then the public key is used to encrypt the secret key and the encrypted secret key is persisted using the private SharedPrefereneces of the app. To load the encrypted files, the encrypted secret key will be decrypted first using the private key.
The Users Identity and Access Data is being retrieved from the OpenID Connect Access Token. \n\nThe remote endpoint terminates the existing session when the user logs out.

There are a number of role checks performed here to indicate if the users Access Token grants them access to a number of predefined roles in the mobile app. \n\nTo enter this view, the user must at least possess the mobile-user role.
